headline.main: AIDS Fighters Face a Resistant Form of Apathy; Searching for Ways to Counter Lax Attitudes and Risky Behavior

docs.abstract: Fight against AIDS among gay men in New York City seems to have weakened as risky behavior and apathy about virus rise; one strong indicator is marked absence of condoms in bars and clubs across city; AIDS activists hold that two significant factors are contributing to rise in risky behavior and HIV infection rate; one is continued popularity of methamphetamine, drug that suppresses sexual inhibitions, leading to unsafe sex; second is appearance of drug company advertisements that minimize impact of HIV infection with portrayals of healthy, active patients; public health experts and psychologists see little hope for change without recognizing and addressing underlying causes of destructive behavior; photos (M)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Where have all the condoms gone? Don't try looking at the Monster, the Hangar, Starlight or Barracuda. On a recent evening, these and more than a dozen other Manhattan gay bars were well stocked with free going-out guides, but not a scrap of literature about H.I.V. prevention or the perils of crystal meth. As for condoms, the frontline defense against sexually transmitted diseases, only one establishment stocked them -- behind the bar.
docs.snippet: Many AIDS activists hold out little hope that news of a rare, possibly more virulent strain of H.I.V. will prompt lasting changes in the behavior of gay men.

headline.main: Remedies Emerging as Issue in Federal Tobacco Case

docs.abstract: Justice Dept continues to prosecute one of most costly civil cases in history, racketeering trial against tobacco industry, now in its seventh month; legal experts and lawmakers debate court remedies versus legislation, such as giving FDA authority over tobacco (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Already one of the most costly civil cases ever prosecuted by the Justice Department, the racketeering trial against the tobacco industry, now in its seventh month, is being heard in two courts and could reach a third, raising questions about what the government might gain with a victory. Testimony continues in the Federal District Court here in a nonjury trial to determine whether the companies hid the adverse health effects of cigarettes for 50 years, as the government contends. Meanwhile, an appeal is already under way to determine the extent of liability if the trial judge rules against the companies.
docs.snippet: The costly racketeering trial being prosecuted by the Justice Department against the tobacco industry is raising questions about what the government might gain with a victory.
